column5:
I wish I had more to say but thank you. Thank you so much for sharing. My sister was in an incredibly similar relationship for three years before she got out, and there were days I worried I‚Äôd never see her again. I‚Äôve also had my fair share of abuse in and out of relationships, as has my other sister. Needless to say, I understand where you were and I send that girl so much love.

You deserve every happiness in life. I hope you find it. ‚ù§Ô∏è And please enjoy that blush pink Christmas tree a little extra for me, my cat won‚Äôt allow me to have one!
You absolutely deserve better than this. I recommend following everybody‚Äôs advice here and getting the ADA involved. ‚ù§Ô∏è Best of luck in whatever you do.

I share a lot of those same beliefs about myself as well. It‚Äôs been a work in progress my whole life to work through them.

I think that mine are rooted in the idea that all of these terrible things that have happened to me must be my fault, because if they weren‚Äôt I‚Äôd have to accept that terrible things can just happen to a person for no reason, and that terrified me more. I wish I had more solid advice for you than to just keep going, but I don‚Äôt. What works for me won‚Äôt necessarily work for you - but what‚Äôs important is that you recognize that you *want* things to change. You have to believe, deep deep down in a corner of your self, that you deserve better and that you can ACHIEVE better.

Healing is possible. But only you will be able to begin that journey for yourself.

It didn‚Äôt necessarily cause me distress, but it definitely fucked with my ideas about what sex was. The first time I saw porn I think I was 6 or 7 years old, and after that I was watching it obsessively for years before I realized that it was fucking me up. The way it shaped my ideas about sex certainly contributed to some of my abuse as a teenager, because I didn‚Äôt *know* that I was being sexually abused in the first place.

You have nothing to apologize for - you realized that you‚Äôd like to know more about how to help your partner who‚Äôs struggling, and you‚Äôre asking for help!! That‚Äôs an incredible and loving thing to do, and you came to a good place. 

I‚Äôm commenting so that I can come back to this in the morning with some advice/experience. ‚ù§Ô∏è

You deserve to feel loved and safe and supported. Congratulations on getting out of that relationship! Instead of asking yourself how you spent four years with that man, congratulate yourself for surviving four years of mistreatment and abuse and celebrate your freedom. All of the love to you. ‚ù§Ô∏è
Oh man this is such a good point. I‚Äôve been feeling a lot safer outside and I think a lot of that comes from having more space from men.

Thank you so much for sharing. Your story is a reminder that the world is better when it‚Äôs experienced with kindness, and that kindness is always possible in the midst of shame and anger. ‚ù§Ô∏è An absolutely necessary reminder.

Charlie will still be with you, in every burst of sunshine and every gust of wind. He‚Äôs waiting for you just on the other side of that bridge, and he knows he‚Äôll see you again one day. ‚ù§Ô∏è Hold onto that love and let it power you through the bad days

I‚Äôm definitely going through similar right now. I‚Äôve been raped a number of times throughout my life, and I‚Äôm currently working through narrative therapy that is helping me place each trauma within a timeline that I can follow. I often feel like if I can just say the ‚Äúthing‚Äù, talk about the flashback, whatever it is, that I will finally feel like I‚Äôll be allowed to heal, that I‚Äôll deserve it.

I had a big breakthrough last week during my session, though. I realized that there isn‚Äôt anything standing in the way between me and compassion for myself, love for myself, belief in my experiences and my own pain. There isn‚Äôt anything *truly* in your way, any one obstacle or therapeutic achievement that has to be met before you can feel better. You just have to approach every moment with compassion for the parts of yourself that are in pain, and recognize that you deserve to feel better. I know it isn‚Äôt easy, but it IS possible.

All of that to say, there is no getting ‚Äúfixed‚Äù with PTSD. There‚Äôs progress, sure, and healing, but the trauma doesn‚Äôt go away. Your symptoms will subside and you‚Äôll learn to deal with your triggers in a way that makes them manageable. You won‚Äôt always feel like you‚Äôre in survivor mode, I promise.

Holy shit, I‚Äôm so proud of you for getting out of this relationship. As I‚Äôm reading this my roommate is actually playing the song my abusive ex played for me when I broke up with him, and I can feel myself dissociating as it‚Äôs happening.

However, your post paired with this at the same time is a reminder to myself that I am out and free, just as you are. You deserve so much love and support from the world around you, and I hope you feel you‚Äôre getting it. ‚ù§Ô∏è Lots of love to you

Bro this hits my ed on the HEAD. I was raped for the first time when I was 14, and subsequently endured assault 4/5 times a week for a few months while in an abusive relationship. My bulimia was in full gear by that point and I didn‚Äôt kick it until I was 22, and even now at 24 i still deal with urges when I start dealing with high periods of anxiety or triggers. I was also raped two other times when I was 18/19 which is when I would relapse from my semi-recovery. Having this approach to understanding my ED is honestly blowing my mind right now.

There‚Äôs nothing terrible about taking care of yourself and your needs - you deserve to be accepted and supported by the people around you, and a pleasant acid trip sounds like a wonderful way to spend Christmas Day!

I‚Äôm 24 years old today (the 22nd) and I‚Äôm still surprised sometimes by my birthdays. I didn‚Äôt always feel like i was going to make it past 18,19,20. Life is so short and there‚Äôs only so much time to experience the joys that make us human beings. I hope you find so many of those joys. I think that you can. I hope that she found them, too. I had disordered tendencies and behaviors as a kid to deal with depression, but it became full blown when I was sexually assaulted by a boyfriend my freshman year of high school. It‚Äôs funny to me that society teaches people to think that EDs are about vanity because I wanted to be as undesirable as humanly possible. I hoped maybe that if I looked like walking death nobody would ever hurt me like that again

It has taken me a VERY long time to work on my feelings of shame over confronting my family about things in my past. It‚Äôs very hard to pick yourself up and stand on your own without it, but it‚Äôs so possible too. I‚Äôm so happy my words could help you! I just really resonated with a lot of what you‚Äôd said in your original post, with my own experiences and frustrations surrounding feeling guilty for confronting my abusers.

Sending lots of love your way. ‚ù§Ô∏è

I think guilt is pretty natural for human beings, even in situations like these. When you start to feel guilty about what you texted to him, try and remember that you‚Äôre only doing what you believe is best for you, which is to seek out honesty and treat that lost child with care and respect. You deserve the truth from him, and even if he won‚Äôt ever give it to you, you‚Äôre doing what you have to to honor that past self and the self you are now. There‚Äôs nothing to feel guilty or shameful about in that. ‚ù§Ô∏è

I think that when we face trauma, especially as children, we often end up processing it for the rest of our lives. Not even always in a healing way, because I think we can ‚Äúheal‚Äù and still need to process at the same time. There‚Äôs no shame in doing what you have to, now, to best live your life.

I‚Äôm sorry for what‚Äôs been done to you. You deserve love and kindness from the world around you, and although that hasn‚Äôt always been given you are still here and that says a lot about your resiliency and strength. Thank you for sharing. ‚ù§Ô∏è
I love Alfie so much!
‚ù§Ô∏è

You‚Äôre doing a great job by trying to seek help and support for her. Thank you for watching out for her! Like another poster said, try and suggest doing something together. Even a short (and relaxing) walk would maybe be a good way to get her out of her head for a bit! With time, if you can make that walk a part of your time together and make it enjoyable she might be able to appreciate that time together and feel less anxious about the food, without worrying too much about working off the calories.
So proud of you! There‚Äôs absolutely nothing you need to change about yourself. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Trust yourself and how you feel. That fear of false memories is natural, but you shouldn‚Äôt spend your time criticizing yourself for what *might* be false memory of trauma. Your experiences are valid and your intuition is worth some trust. Be open and honest with your therapist about what‚Äôs going on/your worries/some of those details of abuse (when you‚Äôre ready it‚Äôs share them). The truths will have to come out eventually in order to heal properly from them, but that pain will be survivable. ‚ù§Ô∏è

It‚Äôs amazing to me that I went my entire life without realizing that this wasn‚Äôt healthy or normal in relationships!
‚ù§Ô∏è

While your point obviously still stands, it‚Äôs important not to frame this as a fault of the victim‚Äôs in any way for ‚Äúallowing‚Äù the security to abuse them. Oftentimes when being assaulted, victims freeze up and cannot take action to get away or ask for help. Nobody ‚Äúlets‚Äù themselves be assaulted. Not everybody is in a place when this is happening to be able to step away.
‚ù§Ô∏è
Wishing you two all of the love in the world!

Yes, this was abuse. Your experience is valid and you deserve support and healing from it. I‚Äôm so sorry this happened to you, and I‚Äôm sorry that you‚Äôve had a hard time coming to terms with your experience as well. All forms of sexual trauma are valid and worth attention + support. Just because others have had it ‚Äúworse‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean you aren‚Äôt hurting - your pain is relative to your experiences.

If you‚Äôve broken an arm, it doesn‚Äôt affect you to a lesser degree because somebody‚Äôs lost a leg. You‚Äôre hurting as you need to, and you deserve to heal as much as anybody else.

Love to you ‚ù§Ô∏è
